title: 109_hr3097
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Federal Employee Protection of Disclosures Act" and clarifies the disclosures covered. Section 2302(b)(8) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to broaden the scope of protected disclosures by employees or applicants without restrictions on time, place, form, motive, context, or prior disclosure. Section 2302(b)(8) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to broaden the scope of protected disclosures by employees or applicants without restrictions on time, place, form, motive, context, or prior disclosure. The amendment includes allowing disclosures of information believed to be evidence of any violation (other than a violation of this section). SEC. 3. COVERED DISCLOSURES. Amends Section 2302(a)(2) of title 5, United States Code to define 'disclosure' as a communication that evidences a violation of law, gross mismanagement, waste of funds, abuse of authority, or danger to public health or safety. 

SEC. 4. REBUTTABLE PRESUMPTION. Section 2302(b) of title 5, United States Code is amended to allow the rebuttal of any presumption related to an employee's duty to disclose information about violations of law, mismanagement, waste of funds, abuse of authority, or danger to public health or safety. SEC. 5. NONDISCLOSURE POLICIES, FORMS, AND AGREEMENTS. The text chunk discusses the amendment of personnel action and prohibited personnel practice related to the implementation or enforcement of nondisclosure policies, forms, or agreements. The provisions outlined do not override employee obligations under various laws and regulations, including those related to disclosures to Congress, military members, illegality, waste, fraud, abuse, public health or safety threats, and national security. The agreement incorporates definitions, requirements, obligations, rights, sanctions, and liabilities from Executive orders and statutory provisions. It prohibits conducting investigations on employees or applicants for protected activities. SEC. 6. EXCLUSION OF AGENCIES BY THE PRESIDENT. Amends Section 2302(a)(2)(C) of title 5, United States Code, to exclude certain agencies from protection. SEC. 7. DISCIPLINARY ACTION. Section 1215(a)(3) of title 5, United States Code, is amended to allow the Merit Systems Protection Board to impose disciplinary actions such as removal, reduction in grade, debarment, suspension, or reprimand, as well as civil penalties up to $1,000 for prohibited personnel practices. The Board must impose disciplinary action if the protected activity was the primary motivating factor, unless the employee proves otherwise. The Merit Systems Protection Board can impose disciplinary actions for prohibited personnel practices, including removal, reduction in grade, debarment, suspension, or reprimand, as well as civil penalties up to $1,000. The employee must prove that the protected activity was not the primary motivating factor for the personnel action. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on security clearance revocations post-1996 for personnel who filed claims under chapter 12 of title 5, United States Code. The study will examine the number of clearances revoked and restored, and any relationship between claim resolution and clearance restoration. A report on the study results must be submitted by June 30, 2006, to specific committees. This Act will take effect 30 days after enactment.
